And then the system let her down along the way. It is often rejected in her tenacity for getting on with the job and unwillingness to apologise for it. But in retrosight the sources of discomfort are plain to see and often made no more acceptable by students themselves accepting that the atmosphere is not ideal given outright blatantly-sexist language and behaviour.
She has borne her experiences bravely – sometimes, strangely so, as they happened to other people. And this has taken more courage than to scream “it is YOUR fault and how could you have not noticed ???!!!!!!!!!”

In one well-controlled laboratory, Andrew Fraknoi at Foothill College in Los Altos Hills in California, together with five collaborators, shows signs of life on a former giant gas planet.
The team measured the effect on a hidden planet, when one third of all molecules in the atmosphere became transparent. These molecules could be evidence of alien life - perhaps in the form of huge animal-infested fields of algae known as blooms.
While the team's story remains unproven, it's sure to increase the appeal of inclinations to discover weird life, rather than just life "as usual". In all, says Fraknoi, life is increasingly dependent on gases and gases are not so predictable.

again and again, is passion.
Consider the way foods speak. Look at a bowl of corn soup, corn kernels polka-dotting the top into which little flecks of butter slip.
That soup says "fall harvest" and it's downright musical with its autumn colors of red and white. It whispers a message that people may not have heard for years, what used to belong within spitting distance and a heady breath of their mother's cooking.
Fancy technique may turn such a soup from a casserole to a presentation, but what gets it there is a simple touch of passion.
If your cooking is colorful and exciting, you don't need heavy piquant accents of marks or seasons. Everything you do is designed to work together, to complement each other, enjoying one another's differences and being married together in the stamp of your personal style.

Brearley’s ascent to the captaincy of England shows how the fixtures timetable determines the class membership of a team.
Had he not been in Oxford, and got to know an older man who lived nearby, Brearley might well not have become a cricketer at all. Had he not had to make the long journey to his college’s playing fields during his novitiate there, he might very well not have done either. This affords him a testament to the wide variations in circumstances that underlie what might seem arbitrary, or just plain accident. Who is awarded captaincy? Who makes a commentary? Who captains the national team? We can now divine some of the cause of captains gaining their appointment but so much is left to chance.

ZeeMee is a new crowd-sourcing social network for students to show their trusts and aspirations by sharing achievements — including photos and videos, rather than just an application.
"The platform is designed to help students share more than a resume. With the stakes of college enrollment rising, students – particularly low-income students and first-generation students – may fear that they have to make difficult trade-offs about how to demonstrate their value in other contexts," said the founders. "They want to demonstrate their values and aspirations beyond test scores by telling stories about their accomplishments that matter most to helping us prepare for and win success in unpredictable times."

On Monday, April 9 the city took two actions signaling openness about the possibility of allowing locally-permitted cannabis retail and deliveries in the city’s “green zone,” according to a news release.
The City Council approved amendments to the general plan, R2035, to open the zone for rezoning, which allows the city to move forward with permitting cannabis retailers and delivery businesses. It’s a “green light,” said Mayor Ian Bain. “I am so pleased we are doing this. It couldn’t come soon enough. It feels so long since this began. Our laws cannot keep up with the times.”

. Genetics can determine how men grow hair.
Some men get a pathologic area (lipohistiocytomas) of hair around their armpit. One side of the body grows hair, the other doesn’t.
Concealer products can hide thinned-out hair on the crown and help male pattern hair loss without resorting to surgery. (Credit: Shutterstock)
Men concerned about hair loss usually begin by consulting family and friends. Advice may be sought from hair-replacement centers or from a pharmacist.
Do men lose hair due to stress?
The impact of stress can surely add to the pace of the process in men who already lose hair. While there is a natural progression toward baldness, studies suggest that stress can speed up the process and cause a man’s hair to more rapidly thin or go totally bald.

giving scientists more tools to track levels of atmospheric carbon dioxide over time. Manion, 64, spent much of the next nine years confusing the local police with his concerted, illegal tactics to prevent the development from rising from the rubble of the land he said the "damn gorillas took from him."

larger companies may host thousands of websites, smaller companies can only accommodate a handful. Reseller web hosting allows smaller companies to expand their business by selling server space to their friends and vendors. As a reseller, you make money hosting other websites, but you need to start small.
List all the services you want the company to include on the first page. You want short and easy sentences to tell customers why the host services are so good. Be honest, but do not put a negative or positive tone in your writing.

Division of Life Sciences at the Arizona State University Bob and Diane Smith family Yuma Center measured brain responses to complicated tasks among yoga practitioners and controls after they practiced. Compost can be started in a small area by turning our yard or kitchen waste into a stored enrichment for the soil. But in that confined area, decomposition can be slow without the help of aeration. That help can be provided by “grit” — small-grain rocks — instead of crushed volcanic rock. Grit helps keep plants so rooted that they get the benefits of their own canopy cover, a second canopy of green that provides shade. professionals in finance, property management and health care with complex choices. The mapping process of a decision tree reflects the probability of the decisions' outcomes.
Finance professionals use a decision tree to reflect possible actions based on possible upside and downside events. Options within the tree represent investment risk, such as Washington Mutual or subprime investments in 2007. Accepting the different paths at each choice point involves a calculation and predicting outcomes. For instance, a subprime investment could be the best option for a conservative path to investment risk. At best, it could show financial rewards without financial losses in the worst case; it is an overall risk. If an investment with more upside potential is chosen, the investment has more potential for financial rewards. The tree also shows the most likely rather than worst case scenario. The service represents the second step of Google's cooperation with Taiwan's top motorcycle apparel firm Cosco Corp.
In March 2012, the U.S.-based Web giant and Cosco jointly launched Google Plus-based business group services in Taiwan, a pioneering project uniting both business and social networking functions.
Google will initially be offering road routes on Google Maps, while planning to further expand its motorcycle service.
Cosco is now the first brand to cooperate with Google in the development of its Google Moto service that was on show on Wednesday at the Taipei City Government Office auditorium.

13. The company is working with the community that works on Apache Hive, a component of the Apache Hadoop open source framework popular for handling, analyzing and storing large data-sets in clusters.
One of the primary reasons Hortonworks’ developers took this approach to Hive was to address a common complaint Hadoop people use the entire framework to slice and dice and visualize their data through a series of queries. Most Hadoop frameworks opt for memory-based processing, as they do not micromanage resource allocation in order to free up designated memory channels for inquiry. Other Hadoop frameworks get config-bound as they base much of the task on optimizing these resource configurations for different loads that get rowed in and stored. Hively, on the other hand, is a batch system. As such, resource allocation has to work in the when column for data insertion fetch queries even when the dataset had not yet arrived at the end time.

The article is based presumably on polling evidence, but it fails to disclose where the finding on this question is from. It may be from focus group questions asking respondents who they consider smart.
However, this is misleading inasmuch as the consequences of not calling someone smart (even if it is incorrect) does not affect people in the same way as being described as smart.
Women are seen as more “likeable” than men. They are perceived as less authoritative or dominant, but also more “sincere”. On average, women are described as more emotionally intelligent than men.Men are often perceived as more intelligent because high levels of intelligence are correlated with achievements in STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering and Maths); fewer women are going into these fields. The Premise of Proposition 10
Proposition 10 would remove the restrictions put in place by California legislators (beginning with Costa-Hawkins in 1995) that prevent cities and counties from setting their own limits on rent rises more often than annual.
Why Prop 10 Matters
Californians are now required to apply rental limits annually, but cities and counties could set rates for shorter time spans if allowed under Proposition 10. Some people think rental ceilings set at the state rather than the local level aren’t as effective as short,

alf Kudryavzev of the Russian Academy of Sciences in Moscow, have succeeded for the first time in studying a family of extragalactic radio sources at the highest possible wavelength. The scientists observed the very active luminous galaxies known as blazars at microwave frequencies, for which they had to develop special radio-scanning cameras mounted on a large variety of telescopes.
From a cosmological point of view, blazars are close relatives of the Milky Way. They are galactic nuclei with highly active black holes and the most luminous objects in the Universe. Some of them are among the most powerful quasars and talked about the most mysterious. Since 2013, conflicts within Syria, Lebanon, Iraq and the wider Arab world and beyond have meant that close to 5.6 million people have had to flee their homes, opting for somewhere new which they can feel safer.
Many of these refugees have travelled for a long time, but often times they don’t travel very far, instead fleeing to neighbouring countries such as Lebanon or Jordan.
For the past week, BuzzFeed UK has been looking at the lives of some of the children who have come into Lebanon to find safety and to ask them about their lives now and what their hopes are for the future.
For these children who have had to flee to Lebanon, their future is unclear and many just want to go back home. As far as they know nothing will be waiting for them

As the threat of internal corruption dogs the ranks of border security forces throughout the United States, the Obama administration is contemplating deploying lower-level agents to Mexico for temporary tours away from their typical repair runs along the Southwest's 2,000 mile border with Mexico.
Administration officials say such "rotational tours" -- which are already performed abroad by State Department, Department of Homeland Security and Justice Department officials, and would first be extended to working border agents rather than training those with their sights set on Caribbean and Central American shores -- could get rid of any Mexico-based corruption and complacency problems.
For the agents who would rotate Stateside, in seven months, those stationed in the Lone Star State and Arizona would do their regular duties aboard the southern barriers they patrol from different, out-of-state sentinel posts.

General Data Protection Regulation (GDPR), a sweeping plan to protect our privacy and give the public control over how their data is shared online, officially went into effect May 25. It might not have the industry buzz of the G Suite rollout like a few weeks ago, but you can’t be active with business processes without being aware of one of the largest overhauls of data protection and privacy laws on record.

An eagerly awaited report from the World Health Organization (WHO) states that processed meats such as bacon and sausages cause cancer, and red meat likely does so too.
The France-based International Agency for Research on Cancer (IARC), which is a division of the WHO, has released its evaluation of over 800 potential carcinogens, and has made the seemingly obvious decision that processed meats – foods high in salt, nitrates, and other chemical treatments – and red meat are both bad for your health.
Does not contain 3% of processing
As it turns out, it’s the processing and pickling that gives pig, beef, and other meats their addictive taste, and high exposure to these factors increases a person’s risk of colorectal and prostate cancer dramatically, based on discussions with cancer experts, published data on nitrite and cancer risk, and results of observational studies. Americans will either see their nation run out of cash next month or face a partial government shutdown in October, a time when Washington would have to note default on the national debt.
U.S. stocks rose slightly while government bond prices traded unevenly, reflecting persistent and potent uncertainty over coming debt fights over the budget, debt limits and everything in between.

She was academically brilliant, the shining light of a community that has seen many potentially intelligent girls given no sniff at education and many dropping out along the way.
Then she got a lifeline. UCC had only ten places for girls to study medicine, Ireland-firsts for women usually came under them, and when she resounded from the region that was where she was headed, encouraged by a scrupulously fair article proclaiming how she was doing only what women had been doing for longer in more dubious times.
And then the system let her down along the way. It is often rejected in her tenacity for getting on with the job and unwillingness to apologise for it. But in retrosight the sources of discomfort are plain to see and often made no more acceptable by students themselves accepting that the atmosphere is not ideal given outright blatantly-sexist language and behaviour.
She has borne her experiences bravely – sometimes, strangely so, as they happened to other people. And this has taken more courage than to scream “it is YOUR fault and how could you have not noticed ???!!!!!!!!!”

WASHINGTON (AP) — Democratic lawmakers must soon decide whether President Barack Obama is leading them toward statesmanlike courage or political folly.
Obama used his first State of the Union speech Wednesday night to try to recast a re-election campaign narrative about the struggling economy into an agenda for America. He declared the nation is primed for change and challenging those who think the next generation is destined for a “low grade” of prosperity.
Hard-line Republicans could characterize that challenge as bloviating Obama, sacrificing the president’s authority by seeking to do so much that he stands no chance of succeeding. Disaffected independents could see a courageous leader willing to leave re-election risk behind to do what he believes is right.

Robert E. Gates, 65, Altoona, passed away Friday at UPMC Altoona.
Known as Flip, he was born in Massachusetts, son of the late Patricia Gates. He married Jackie Kopecek on May 6, 1976, in Worden.
Robert worked in the maintenance department for the I.L. Doubleday business office in Virginia. He lived in Altoona and Fredericktown most recently.
A father and devoted son and brother and grandfather, he enjoyed oil painting and wood carving. He had a desire to fix things, and he enjoyed gardening. He was a devoted fan of the Ohio State Buckeyes and Cincinnati Reds.
Surviving are his wife; two daughters, Jodi Greenhill and husband Jeffrey and Cynthia Gates, all of Fredericktown; two grandchildren, Addison and Olivia Greenhill; two brothers, Dave and his wife, Ellen, and Steve, and two sisters, Barbara Southard and her husband, Denis, and Mary .
He was preceded in death by one brother, Larry, and a brother

Why are American women dying in childbirth?
Maternal mortality rates are falling in every industrialised nation - except for the United States.
The United States is not the first place that springs to mind when considering women dying in childbirth; Ireland would be more likely. Ireland ranked highest for maternal mortality with 18 deaths per 100,000 births in 2015 according to the latest statistics from the World Health Organization, compared with the United States, which ranked 68th with 11 deaths in every 100,000.
However; this trend of women from other industrialised nations left with high numbers across women’s death in childbirth has recently been discovered by American research. After digging deeply into the numbers, it became clear to the authors behind the study that American women are indeed putting parenthood before their own health. The results of the study were presented at a conference in Chicago.

Wilson threw a 13-yard touchdown pass to Golden Tate and Marshawn Lynch added a 24-yard TD run, Seattle's defense held, and the Seahawks beat the Carolina Panthers for the seventh straight time by holding on for a 12-7 win on Sunday.
Newton finished 15-of-32 for 145 yards, one touchdowns and two interceptions for the Panthers (1-2) in the latest meeting between the two quarterbacks since the infamous postgame incident last year. Both Wilson and Newton had easy ways to win the matchup, but a poor second half did them both in.

Nike Inc enjoyed big sales in gains in North America and Europe last quarter and benefited from fewer markdowns, helping the maker of sports clothes and shoes report a stronger-than-expected quarterly profit.
Total revenue increased 6% in dollar terms to $6.42 billion (£4.60 billion) on a currency-neutral basis. A year-ago total was $5.22 billion.
Core Nike Brand revenue rose 12%. Combined revenue from its Nike and Jordan shoe brands, Converse, Women's Training and Nike running rose 6% in local currency terms.
USA and Greater China revenue gained 5.2 % and 10.5%, respectively, helping drive a 7.3% gain for NIKE Brand sales. North America revenues were up 7.3%, driven by double-digit growth in Running and Jordan Brand in United States.

WHEN predicting which planets beyond Earth could support life, astronomers usually follow the water. Exoplanets with rocky surfaces are declared habitable if they orbit far enough from their star to potentially host oceans.
But as astronomers celebrated the finding of a candidate Earth cousin this June, another type of classifier may have just plugged a vital detail into our detection algorithms. In one well-controlled laboratory, Andrew Fraknoi at Foothill College in Los Altos Hills in California, together with five collaborators, shows signs of life on a former giant gas planet.
The team measured the effect on a hidden planet, when one third of all molecules in the atmosphere became transparent. These molecules could be evidence of alien life - perhaps in the form of huge animal-infested fields of algae known as blooms.
While the team's story remains unproven, it's sure to increase the appeal of inclinations to discover weird life, rather than just life "as usual". In all, says Fraknoi, life is increasingly dependent on gases and gases are not so predictable.

Most gardeners think of diascias as low-growing bedding plants suited to a summer container or the front of a sunny border.
However Diascia personata breaks the mould and produces stiff stems of mid-green or bronze-green, fragrant foliage which is equally at home in winter containers as it is in summer borders. Often grown in formal spring flower arrangements in SA, you won't find many perennial young plants at garden centres, but good-sized ones are distributed by friends and knowledgeable enthusiasts. It is self-branching, sweetly fragrant, and compostable when it finishes its floral season in September.

GENEVA, Mar 18 2013 (IPS) - The current growth model is not sustainable. Neither the green economy nor alternative sources of energy can prevent global warming. Solutions will come only through a profound overhaul of business and consumption practices worldwide. That is according to new UNCTAD (United Nations Conference on Trade and Development) eco-tariffs for over 1000 products, which force consumers in rich countries to pay more for what they consume.
However, both public pressure and political will may well be needed to skew traditional markets – currently driven by maximal profitability – towards sustainability.
“In the policy considerations that lie behind the eco-tariffs of the new report are the potential economic effects that can be achieved in terms of moderating environmental impacts and other aspects of sustainability. These may alter competition results,” says UNCTAD, adding that it would be impossible to advocate price instruments to promote the environment as ideologically, administrative or logistical imperatives. Therefore, the world body is providing information and technical support, for which it was created.

Many people think the secret to great cooking is mastery of technique.
It helps, but it's hardly crucial. The key to cooking that tempts and satisfies, that brings people to the table, then brings them back again and again, is passion.
Consider the way foods speak. Look at a bowl of corn soup, corn kernels polka-dotting the top into which little flecks of butter slip.
That soup says "fall harvest" and it's downright musical with its autumn colors of red and white. It whispers a message that people may not have heard for years, what used to belong within spitting distance and a heady breath of their mother's cooking.
Fancy technique may turn such a soup from a casserole to a presentation, but what gets it there is a simple touch of passion.
If your cooking is colorful and exciting, you don't need heavy piquant accents of marks or seasons. Everything you do is designed to work together, to complement each other, enjoying one another's differences and being married together in the stamp of your personal style.

California is lifting its drought emergency for most of the state after a winter of record rain and snowfall that followed a five-year dry spell.
Gov. Jerry Brown's office announced Friday that his executive order will lift all but three counties from a drought declaration that had been in place since 2011.
Brown ordered that emergency be lifted Oct. 4 but their region has not had sufficient rain totals.
Fresno, Kern and Kings counties can expect to be lifted on April 4, when a spring rainy season and possible winter storms are expected.

IF you like cricket, and like a brainy writer whose intellectualism is friendly and endearing, you’d better read this book. Mike Brearley was a cricketer with modest abilities, but he possesses a magnificent intelligence. It is simply a joy to read his words.
Brearley’s ascent to the captaincy of England shows how the fixtures timetable determines the class membership of a team.
Had he not been in Oxford, and got to know an older man who lived nearby, Brearley might well not have become a cricketer at all. Had he not had to make the long journey to his college’s playing fields during his novitiate there, he might very well not have done either. This affords him a testament to the wide variations in circumstances that underlie what might seem arbitrary, or just plain accident. Who is awarded captaincy? Who makes a commentary? Who captains the national team? We can now divine some of the cause of captains gaining their appointment but so much is left to chance.

A 35-year-old Fond du Lac man was traveling north on County Road BB, just south of Benjamin Avenue, when the vehicle ran off the road, state crash records show. As the man tried to drive back on the road, the car hit a ditch and overturned.
Jonathon R. Harmman of Fond du Lac and a 79-year-old Winnebago man in Harmman's car weren't wearing seat belts and were thrown from the car.
Both men were taken by ambulance and flown via helicopter to Froedtert Memory and Mission Care in Fond du Lac, according to records. Harmman was listed Friday in good condition while the man was in fair condition in the intensive care unit at Froedtert, according to a hospital spokeswoman.

Jalapenos are used in many spicy dishes and used fresh, dried eaten pickled.
Jalapeno peppers are among the warm-season hot peppers of the Solanaceae family. Hot peppers grow well in the course of spring, summer, and the beginning of autumn in a dry period garden that has rich soil and at least four or five hours of full sunlight every day. All hot peppers, jalapenos included, share a similar growing process. There isn't a lot to plant them: soil, water, nutrients and some sunlight.
All of the jalapenos should be nourished from July to October. End-of-September prune back or pinch-out the plants are finished, that will help them to generate less fruits as they will give attention to the developing new leaves to recover for the coming season.
To get fruits, flowering will begin. When pods begin to come out, pull out the crop so they are able to grow to their maturation for around 70 to 100 days, depending on season and weather. Monitor plants

Mismanagement and secrecy have stalled the war on terrorism—and at home its effects reverberate against civil rights.
If September 11 was this generation's Pearl Harbor, the Bush Administration's war on terrorism will soon become a 30-year slog, sapping the strength from our country and closing numerous avenues of freedom for most Americans. Like the war in country after country which followed our own revolution, Iraq today serves as a base that engenders war, and a bulwark for more wide-spread conservative policy for this nation's balance of power. In a topsy-turvy, Bush-antagonized land, this concerted action—coupled with confusion and lack of vision—now meets significant trepidations. A neutrino event, identifiable by the rings of Cerenkov radiation that show up along the photomultiplier tubes lining the detector walls, showcase the successful methodology of neutrino astronomy. This method is low in background since the event must show a sharp pulse, multiple tubes firing approximately at once, with rapidly decreasing (yet audible) photomultiplier tube output after their respective first photon emission.
Neutrino astronomy (a pioneering scientific subject that refers to astronomical applications only dealing with neutrinos rather than other subatomic particles), traditionally requires large radio antennas tuned to a particular wavelength, capable of detecting low–state (i.e., non-thermal) radio observations, in other words, radio bursts that are not associated with the source of emission directly (a known star, object or celestial body). These results need to be discarded, specifically: 10%. Assemblages below a lower bound are produced by known sources. These need not be discarded, specifically: 5%. Chinese cities, provinces and companies can now emit up to 10,000 tons of carbon dioxide annually for 90 euros. For each additional ton of emission, allowances cost 90 euros. Companies that emit so much emissions must then buy CO2 permits at whose cost manufacturers at carbon leakage risk remain competitive. MUMBAI (Reuters) - Foxconn Technology is in talks to manufacture Apple’s iPhone in India, government officials said, in a move that could lower prices in the world’s No.3 smartphone market for the world’s No.1 brand.
Apple sources said the pricing could be lower for India by 15-17 percent, provided Foxconn, which makes in the area of 150 million units a year for Apple in China, can provide “competitive, quality overall solution.”
“Apple is still in talks with contract manufacturers based in India,” a person with direct knowledge told Reuters this week.
“Foxconn has already started material production and talks, including cellphones, Apple Watches and other hardware. They are doing small volumes of testing at present, using materials from China,” he said on Friday.

Students have long applied to colleges and universities with applications that are heavy on test scores and grades. While that's not necessarily wrong, the founders of ZeeMee believe it doesn't tell the whole story.
ZeeMee is a new crowd-sourcing social network for students to show their trusts and aspirations by sharing achievements — including photos and videos, rather than just an application.
"The platform is designed to help students share more than a resume. With the stakes of college enrollment rising, students – particularly low-income students and first-generation students – may fear that they have to make difficult trade-offs about how to demonstrate their value in other contexts," said the founders. "They want to demonstrate their values and aspirations beyond test scores by telling stories about their accomplishments that matter most to helping us prepare for and win success in unpredictable times."

Granite Geek: When is a drought not a drought?
Right now in Concord, we are living in a meteorological puzzle: The National Weather Service says this is the wettest August since records began being kept in 1897. A state climatologist says we’re not experiencing a drought. And NASA’s satellite data is reliably stating that New England is experiencing its second-wettest year on record.
When all of that data is combined, the result is a powerfully counterintuitive state of mind: It’s too wet out here to be experiencing a drought.

SITIAWAN — The incident where four vernacular school students suffered burns during a school project was attributed to an accident, and not negligence.
Perak Education, Technology, Science, Environment and Information committee chairman Dr Daroyah Sayang had called for an investigation to determine the cause of the accident.
She also described the lack of a written safety checklist for caustic soda, a key component to the project as unacceptable.
“The teacher said laundry soap would do but there’s a difference because it contains fatty materials,” said Dr Darayah.
“If the agency that taught this workedshops had followed proper procedures there would not have been this accident,” asserted the PAS state deputy-commissar.
She also dent out that the teacher handling the project at Kang Cheng High School shouldn’t be infantilising the students, thus giving them grounds to act recklessly when handling sophisticated chemicals.

The U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission today charged the estate of Florida investment firm executive K. Wayne McLeod with running a Ponzi scheme that victimized an estimated 125 investors, mostly near Tampa, for more than $45.7 million through four affiliated hedge funds.
An SEC administrative hearing tomorrow is expected to shed light on the extensive efforts McLeod made over six years to hide the excessive trading and mark-ups within the hedge funds.
To appear legitimate, McLeod fabricated reported profits through phony and unauthorized trades, and back-dated important documents. The mark-ups were hidden with false books and records and falsely inflated returns. The pervasive practice damaged investors’ and broker-dealers’ legitimate investing, compromised the integrity of financial disclosure and undermined investor confidence.
McLeod also operated businesses to provide investors unrelated products and calculators that created the false appearance of profitability in the hedge funds.

What can poetry do when faced with the daily realities of war and hatred, violence and terror, the crimes that humans enact upon each other and on the Earth? A cynic would answer nothing, would condemn the personal gesture of poetry and quail at the prospect of the global effort. Albert Camus’s beautiful essay “The Calm Before the Storm” imagines a late-night conversation with Lucid & Tempti, two airmen returning from the front, in search of a song:
All the early songs still played on my record-player. I took them out one by one, and from the lighted window I looked at my best friend. He listened to each song with unwavering concentration, sustaining a serious gaze all through the air battle scene, the technicolored dance number with their daughter, that song he was looking for, and its epilogue. “I hate this kind of music,” he said, “and I’ve grown harder still.”
All the early songs might still play before our cabins tonight also, but now the night is waiting in its corners for its bit of action only. The true calm is gone. “

“Though his opposition to integration was a hallmark of [former South Carolina Senator Strom] Thurmond’s early career, his segregationist past seems all but forgotten …
”I hate to see old people ostracized or put down in any society. I don’t want them to be hurt, and I don’t want anyone hurt on any side of that issue,” he recently said.

Most notably, he called upon ‘every Negro registered voter in the state to try to ‘break up Negro schools as they are run today.’’
Strom even took time to call upon black people who were members of South Carolina’s Democratic Party to “join the GOP and wipe out the Democrat pattern.”

COLUMBIA, SC (WIS) - James Robert Thomason has owned his liquor store since 2002.
Right now, Thomason’s Wine and Liquor, just like any other liquor store, can only sell alcohol between 10 am and 7 am, but within the next six months the state could see changes only Thomason knows.
“If we’re going to get rid of consumption bars what has to take place? Something has to take place after the consumption bars.” said Thomason.
The liquor store owner says he showed his concern to Attorney General Alan Wilson today. Thomason wants the governor and attorney general to give the green light in the sale of liquor by the drink. This would be alcohol you could buy from stores and bring to a restaurant to consume off-premises.
When asked, James Robert Thomason says he’s not worried that monthly alcohol sales could potentially rise, “They tripled it from 10-12 every month just because they have more to sell. If you have more to sell I have a feeling people will be purchasing more.”

LONDON, May 16 (Reuters) - The pesticide glyphosate, sold by Monsanto in its Roundup weed killer product and widely used in agriculture and by gardeners, does not increase the risk of cancer, according to the body of the European Union’s lead agency.
IARC concluded that glyphosate was “probably carcinogenic to humans” in 2015 after classifying it as being possibly carcinogenic to humans in 1981.
Germany and France both pledged in January to phase out glyphosate-related products by 2022, while the World Health Organization has drawn up plans to set maximum levels of the chemical in food.
Germany said it would encourage local farmers to switch to low-risk products such as organic farming.
France has plans to make the switchovers within four years, including as a condition for most farmers to receive government subsidies under its Common Agricultural Policy (CAP).
IARC will release details on Thursday on how it makes risk

APPLETON – Ed Berthiaume, news director at The Post-Crescent, will step down from his post early next year after 29 years with the news organization.
Berthiaume, 58, who's also been managing editor of the Post-Crescent since 1988, will remain at the newspaper in some capacity after his last day on Jan. 6.
General Manager Heidi Soiko-Czarkowski said in a memo today that Berthiaume will be used in many roles within the Post-Crescent Group after stepping down.
Usually the news staff is staffed based on the day's demand for content. Monday will be Berthiaume's last official day reporting, the northeast Wisconsin daily reported.
Starting July 25, he'll cover a tourism beat, monitoring trends in Wisconsin and surrounding regions while providing local coverage of tourism-related news and events in Fond du Lac and Outagamie counties.

Proclus of Athens (*412–485 C.E.) was the most authoritative philosopher of late antiquity and played a crucial role in the transmission of Platonic philosophy from antiquity to the Middle Ages and early modern times. Proclus represents the continuation of ancient Hellenic philosophy in Neoplatonic interpretation during the 5th and 6th centuries c.e. Apart from Plato and Aristotle, his direct philosophical predecessors in Platonism are Euclid, Plotinus, Jamblichus, and Iamblichus in Alexandria, as well as Damascius of Alexandria and Syrianus in Antioch, where Platonism became a popular philosophical school. Syrianus's influence on the formulation and writing of Proclus's teachings significantly contributed to Proclos's Neoplatonic strategy. Although he drew the line to Christology when he said that God could not have become man, Proclus showed his piety to the Lord Jesus in the enumeration of the Fathers as Proclus shared with Iakovos Zographos: The celebration of the Resurre

Citizens from Australia, Japan, New Zealand, Singapore and the United Kingdom don’t fall within the new rules ─ they will have to undergo the biometric requirement starting in May.
Canada says the move to harness more biographical information from visa applications and the no-fly list will improve security. It’s part of Canada’s efforts to end all visas and replace them with visa-free travel following a deal the Liberals struck last month with the 28-country European Union, Canada’s largest trading partner. One quirk of that deal surrendered valuable visa-free travel privileges to U.S. citizens without requiring parallel rights for Canadians.

Centralizing the procurement process, diversifying supplier portfolios and assessing the capabilities of each manufacturing partner will allow enterprises to mitigate the impact of or eliminate product recalls.
In 1989, one of the world’s largest food companies issued a press release announcing a major recall of eight named brands. Board members were called in to discuss marketing strategies. Dozens of upper managers were summoned to explain corporate governance.
Ten years later they had another recall of the same brands because of ovdoerinspect contained in the brands. And 14 years after that, there was another recall—of a slightly different product and produced in a different mill. Today, big recalls remain big news, no matter which products or which companies sponsor the action. For instance:
• Kraft Foods Inc. issued a nationwide recall in November 2000 of 9 million pounds of Jell-O Snapple ice mix after several people suffered kidney failures attributed to ethylene glycol.

Addressing a business envelope correctly helps ensure that your letter gets to its intended recipient quickly. It’s important to follow standard practices for addressing correspondence, particularly if you are sending a letter to a large company with many departments. People don’t want to open and read a letter addressed to “Business Leadership,” but rather to the President, Vice President, or someone actually involved in the leadership structure of that company. Read on to learn how to address letters correctly, even to large businesses.
How Tab Experts Address Business Envelopes
We’re all familiar with the step-by-step process of addressing a “personal” envelope, but are often caught off guard when we have to address one intended to be passed to a business. But don’t worry—this routine preparation won't leave you looking foolish.
For most organizations, especially larger organizations, using mostly uppercase letters will suffice. But these big companies are still subject to the rules of today's more casual culture. Addressing a business envelope is a matter of looking at which part of a business is headed or which type of mail you're addressing.

CLEVELAND – Two women -- one with a ticket, one tearfully without -- laid claim to a $162 million lottery jackpot Tuesday, triggering a legal dispute that could come down to "finder's keepers."
The women, who all live near Cleveland, contend that their groups had agreed to split winnings close to the jackpot's winning ticket worth about $162 million before one member secretly said she won it Saturday.
One woman, Berlynn Hamilton of Cleveland, showed up at Ohio Lottery headquarters in downtown Cleveland after realizing the group agreed to split any wins if the ticket was sold in Ohio.
Hamilton said she and a group that included three other women -- a friend and two cousins -- met a couple of times last month and agreed to share any winnings if any of them won it. The women wrote down their names on a piece of paper that Houston explained "sounds like a legal document," he said.
Associated Press Writer Herny Weinberger in Washington and AP writer John Seewer in Toledo contributed to this report.

Hair loss is no longer an inevitable march to baldness. Medical advances in recent decades mean male hair loss can be treated, and it need not break the bank.
The cause of male pattern baldness is well established. Genetics can determine how men grow hair.
Some men get a pathologic area (lipohistiocytomas) of hair around their armpit. One side of the body grows hair, the other doesn’t.
Concealer products can hide thinned-out hair on the crown and help male pattern hair loss without resorting to surgery. (Credit: Shutterstock)
Men concerned about hair loss usually begin by consulting family and friends. Advice may be sought from hair-replacement centers or from a pharmacist.
Do men lose hair due to stress?
The impact of stress can surely add to the pace of the process in men who already lose hair. While there is a natural progression toward baldness, studies suggest that stress can speed up the process and cause a man’s hair to more rapidly thin or go totally bald.

Clarithromycin belongs to the group of medications called macrolide antibiotics. It is used to treat infections caused by certain bacteria. It works by killing or stopping the growth of bacteria that can cause infections. It is most commonly used to treat middle ear infections, bronchitis, and throat infections. It can also treat lung infections such as pneumonia, skin infections, and infections of the sinuses (infections of the passages around the nose).

Newswise — As more carbon dioxide enters the atmosphere, the global ocean soaks up much of the excess, giving scientists more tools to track levels of atmospheric carbon dioxide over time. While both biology and chemistry play roles in how ocean waters take up carbon and most scientists agree that less than 10% of carbon enters the seas from the atmosphere, there’s a heated debate over the exact nature and size of their influence causing much of the public is left without a full picture. The biggest disconnect relates to the uncertainty surrounding iron-rich dust storms over the ocean and their direct effect on the ocean’s ability to soak up carbon.
A new scientific assessment, conducted by an international team of scientists, used new methods to study the fundamental biological and mineral (“chemical and physical”) processes involved with how the ocean absorbs atmospheric carbon. The United Kingdom could still remain a member of the European Union, but only if all other member states agree, said the leader of the second-largest political group in the European Parliament.
“Our door remains open, if the UK wants to join us in overcoming these challenges through two years or more, of course, but I want in negotiating positions in which everyone can take this position that membership of the European Union is possible only conditional on the UK remaining a part of the internal integration process of the EU,” Martin Schulz, the leader of the Socialists and Democrats EU group, told Deutsche Welle.
The European Parliament chief remarks were made after British Prime Minister David Cameron announced on Wednesday that would leave the UK EU if his party was re-elected; a move that Brussels now regards as potentially predicated to Grexit. Researchers are zooming in on a handheld camera that can reveal the unseen, inner structures of everything from concrete bridges to body parts.
Remember those X-ray glasses advertised in the back of comic books decades ago? Sure, they looked like fun, but their performance was little better than a sugar pill — anything that did anything would have seriously damaged your retinas.
After all, you need a lot more power for X-ray vision than was provided by simple toy optics. Yet here's a handheld laser-based video-imaging device that peers a few microns into the inner structure of surfaces and yields details better than conventional ultra-high-resolution optical microscopes and scanners.
On Laboratory Day in April 2007, an international team of scientists from the U.S. Department of Energy's (DOE) Argonne and Oak Ridge national laboratories showed this compact but powerful prototype to visitors to their stand at the biennial meeting of the American Association for the Advancement of Science and invited one onto the machine to take a peek.

Nuance Communications has announced that IP Australia will become the first organisation across the Asia Pacific region to add next generation automated machine learning and human-assisted artificial intelligence (AI) capabilities to its widely successful Alex online virtual assistant.
Alex is IP Australia's first-generation Avcomm solution that empowers examiners to make more strategic, impactful decisions by streamlining their day-to-day workflow processes, allowing them to work more accurately and with greater efficiency with improved access to IP data in less time. IP Australia, an AU$108-million division of the Australian government, was one of the early adopters of Alex in 2013 and has achieved strong adoption of this solution among examiners. This transition into an Avcomm solution follows Hinzen Patent Information Services’ adoption of an Avcomm implementation earlier this year.
State-of-the-art machine learning technology is used to train an adaptive model, called an intent model, and supported by informative content and rules from 6,000 intellectually prepared How-to guides, to automatically shape solutions and meet the ever- changing human needs.

2016 is poised to be the year that virtual reality really gets going, as Oculus Rift, PlayStation VR and HTC Vive all hit the market in earnest.
That, according to SuperData Research, which says that theVR headset market will grow from just $170 million this year to more than $7 billion by 2022.

A man from Alsip has been charged with the fatal shooting of a 33-year-old man in the South Chicago neighborhood, police said.
Brandon Ewing, 24, of the 3700 block of South Alsdorf Avenue, was charged with first-degree murder in the Oct. 15 slaying of Herbert Thomas III, according a statement from Chicago Police Department.
Thomas was standing on the porch of a house in the 900 block of East 106th St. when another man came up and shot him, Chicago police said.
Thomas subsequently drove home in the 16700 block of Carmen Street, where he died at the scene.
Prosecutors said Ewing is “armed and dangerous and should be considered armed and dangerous,” and investigators believe there may be additional witnesses not yet interviewed because of Ewing’s alleged connection to gangs. Police gave no indication whether the shooting was gang-related.

CAIRO (Reuters) - Egyptian police on Sunday arrested the author of a book about Egypt's economy on charges of publishing false news, security sources and the author's wife said.
Abdul Khalik Farag, who wrote a column in Reuters in the early 1980s, was a founding member of the Centre for Investment Studies, a think tank, in a joint venture with the IMF designed to jump-start Egypt's stagnant economy.
Security sources said Farag was charged with publishing false news that affected the national economy, and would normally be held for 48 days before a court ordered his release or formally charged him. Lawyers for the 83-year-old denied all charges.
"The book is a critique of the ruling establishment; they are trying hard to stop it… so they arrested my father on false charges," plumber Aya Abdul Kalaam said.
"The only reason is that it's in bookshops," she said, adding it had been published some months earlier. "This is no excuse in any civilised state."

LONDON (ICIS)--Italy-headquartered energy group Eni is readying its Ravenna plant for a 50% capacity expansion during maintenance in August, a company source said on Tuesday.
Information from Platts Analytics suggested that sufficient feedstock availability, adequate dock space, a longerthan-usual turnaround and scheduled maintenance flexibility have presented a good opportunity to absorb additional online volumes.
“August is the most critical month as volume expansions help them to reduce the market share they allocated for barley when this oilseeds source was bought up,” the energy trader source said.
“It is a good opportunity for Eni to increase its barley and guar product slate. Until July 25, they are looking for old-crop global linseed,” the source added.
Around 500,000 tonnes of old-crop sunflowerseed consumption is also on offer with German-sourcing growing in momentum for late contracts, the Platts Analytics source noted.

BOSTON (AP) — An Amtrak employee suffered an apparent heart attack and later died after a train struck a piece of construction equipment near where he was working early Thursday morning, officials said.
The Albany, N.Y.-to-New York, N.Y., train derailed its first car and hit the construction equipment around 3:30 a.m outside Springfield, said Lisa Ekoue Blyden, spokeswoman of the National Transportation Safety Board. There were no reported passenger injuries, although one employee suffered an injury, she said.
Ekoue Blyden said it's too soon to finger the cause of the accident, although she said the equipment used on the work site is designed to be removed before any track work occurs.
The employee was working in a secure area next the track, she said.
NTSB says an Amtrak employee who was working near the train tracks in Springfield was hospitalized after it hit this construction trailer around 3:30 a.m. Thursday.

Colorado legislators have narrowly voted in a bill that would establish state-run financial services for marijuana sellers, in an effort to ease the cash-only burden afflicting commercial weed distributors.
The bill passed by a 31 to 30 vote in the state legislature, reports The Denver Post, and now awaits the approval of Governor John Hickenlooper, a Democrat whose party is at risk of being polled out of political power in Colorado.
According to CNBC, the bill would create a system of banks tied directly to the state-licensed dispensaries to help ease their financial-transaction woes. Right now, marijuana sellers who receive cash payments cannot deposit the funds in their business'-owning bank accounts without getting nailed by the DEA or federal authorities. They are unsure how to tie those funds in with their online payment systems — or what they will be fined by federal authorities for attempting to acquire the system.
Already, the number of banks serving Colorado marijuana customers have shrunk from 20, according to CNBC.

Stamford's Old Town Hall Redevelopment Agency this week chose Nov. 19 for the opening ceremony for the renovated Old Town Hall building.
Both Mayor Dannel Malloy and the new mayor elected that week, George Longmore or Joseph Serra, will lead the celebration.
Old Town Hall, originally built in 1904 and funded through tax collections and a lottery, has undergone almost total renovation and restoration since its original architect, B. S. Wainwright, died in 1908.
Old Town Hall’s history began long before most of its present guests were born. The current kitchen had once fed thousands of boarding house guests. The back room with the rows of cast-iron grape vines that were hand-painted is actually an original Edison meter closet with a numeric gauge. The cast-iron grape pattern continued outside of the back windows on the lava stone wall.

The final group of Irish peacekeepers to serve in Chad arrived back in Dublin this afternoon.
For the first time in three decades, there are now no large Irish battalions serving overseas.
The 18 to come home arrived back at Casement Aerodrome in Baldonnel, Co Dublin, this afternoon.
Many of the personnel said they had positive experiences, learn't a lot and made many friends during their stint in the area.

The US economy “remains strong”, the Federal Reserve chairman, Jerome Powell, told Congress on Tuesday as he signaled the central bank is on course to carry on gradually increasing interest rates in the coming months.
In his prepared opening statement, Powell said GDP growth has rebounded in recent quarters and showed signs of firming in the first half of this year.
He said inflation measures remain subdued and further below the Fed’s 2% goal following several annual increases of less than 2%. Overall, the goals for inflation and labor market measures indicate that the current stance of monetary policy remains appropriate in seeking to ensure the jobs growth is sustained, he added.
One of the biggest questions hanging over the Fed’s interest rate setting decisions is whether Donald Trump might be looking for a way to get the central bank to cut rates even as Trump and his associates have become increasingly critical of Powell and the Fed.

2 Can You Make Money Being a Web-hosting Reseller?
Web hosting companies earn money by selling server space to individuals and businesses. While some larger companies may host thousands of websites, smaller companies can only accommodate a handful. Reseller web hosting allows smaller companies to expand their business by selling server space to their friends and vendors. As a reseller, you make money hosting other websites, but you need to start small.

Earth requires fuel to drive plate tectonics, volcanoes and its magnetic field. Like a hybrid car, Earth taps two sources of energy to run its engine: primordial energy from assembling the planet and nuclear energy produced in Earth’s interior. It is thought that primordial energy comes from radioactive elements that are created late in Earth’s formation.
Recent studies estimate Earth’s energy budget, by narrowing down the power consumption and production of magma, faults and the core via reconciling how much energy Earth must be getting to balance its energy budget. For example, throughout their entire lifetime, mountain belts produce five to 10 times the amount of heat they suck up from other parts of Earth. Our calculations reveal that, over a timescale of more than a billion years, the amount of heat plate tectonic zones produce is similar to that produced through radioactive decay (a source of nuclear energy). This may seem surprising as estimates of the amount of heat produced at a subduction zone, which is where one tectonic plate is sliding beneath another plate, range from a few to ten times greater. (CNN) — Elephants are giant, cancer-battling super creatures that destroy damaged cells long before they become cancerous, scientists say.
In a study released this week, scientists said elephant cells known as “mesenchymal stem cells” detected a problem inside the animal before the cancer started.
Whether that information eventually helps fight cancer in public, like radiotherapy, or whether it will be modified to help fight illness, is exciting research, the scientists said.
Elephants are thought to be the largest land animal in the world. They are also one of the few animals known to have cancer. In most species, zoologists say, such problems may occur because cancer is often a treatable disease, but elephants are unique creatures that resist illness.
Cell Division Center for Elephant Conservation (NDDR), formerly the Institute of Mammals of Karno Pasture), a partner in the study from China, found that electroporation is a pain relief method.

Yogis may be enjoying a surprising benefit when they unroll their mats and strike a pose. A new study finds that just 20 minutes of hatha yoga stimulates brain function.
Researchers from the Division of Life Sciences at the Arizona State University Bob and Diane Smith family Yuma Center measured brain responses to complicated tasks among yoga practitioners and controls after they practiced. In both groups’ brains, they found an increase in activity centered on certain key brain regions used for specific cognitive functions (visual perception regions, brain structures involved in vision and language, and brain regions that enable awareness, i.e., moral and emotional turmoil).
Previous research had shown a relationship between meditation and spatial domains of visuospatial processing in the “tree pattern,” which occurs in the brain’s left hemisphere and involves visual navigation. The meditation research also showed that the more regularly you practice, the stronger the correlations become.

Composting is the ultimate win-win-win for gardeners.
It is recycling at its most basic, turning yard and kitchen waste into rich, organic planting material. It saves money on fertilizer and chemical herbicides, reduces waste, and allows soil to store water better, all while enriching the Great Outdoors. Compost is delivered in a yard-ready end product that is organic and contains essential micro elements that plants can absorb.
Compost can be started in a small area by turning our yard or kitchen waste into a stored enrichment for the soil. But in that confined area, decomposition can be slow without the help of aeration. That help can be provided by “grit” — small-grain rocks — instead of crushed volcanic rock. Grit helps keep plants so rooted that they get the benefits of their own canopy cover, a second canopy of green that provides shade. Given enough clumps of grit to cover the whole top of the pile, compost bins filled with kitchen scraps will give you a yard rotation, or turn, every one to four years, depending on

Home Procurement News Why is lean accounting necessary in the supply chain?
Why is lean accounting necessary in the supply chain?
Knowing how to manage your finances is important for any business. If you aren't able to accurately interpret your financial records, it becomes more difficult to make changes and pinpoint wasteful aspects of your business. That could prove problematic in Purchasing, where the scope of tasks dealing with finances includes not just determining production costs and maintaining good relationships with supply partners — it's also important to develop strategic sourcing, with a clear grasp on how materials will best serve your organization. If you ever find yourself asking questions about financial concerns outside of procurement itself, it's vital to have a working mastery of lean accounting – and that's a vital mechanism that can allow you to help your organization excel.
Lean accounting is meant itself to be focused: cutting out all the unnecessary bulk that gives offending resources the illusion of being valuable.
Business renovations can be hard to get used to without knowing how to derive tangible data from any given subject. Lean thinking takes all biases away

Alaska's distilleries can no longer serve mixed drinks to customers, the state agency overseeing alcohol ruled Tuesday.
In a 3-1 vote, the Alcoholic Beverage Control announcement means the fixture of many breweries – bars that serve patrons mixed drinks alongside their gin and beer – are going away.
The reason, said Alaska ABC spokesperson Bill Pruitt, is because parties began mixing drinks themselves.
“The reason we’re doing this is customer complaints of basically they didn’t like how the client wasn’t going to serve themselves drinks anymore but they wanted us to sell them alcohol,” he said.
The Alaska ABC’s order distinguishes distilleries by allowing all breweries, wineries, and distilleries with a permit that allows them to serve on-premises sales to keep serving alcohol to their customers, even if they ain’t mixing drinks. Only distilleries that don’t have as much alcohol variety can no longer sell mixed drinks to their clientele.

Which Irish names are making a comeback?
For the fifth year in a row, Emily was the most popular female baby name in Ireland in 2015. Emily finished the year ahead of Emma, Ava, Isabella and Sophie by one baby each. You would think slow changes meant the name has been constant and popular for a long time, but it wasn’t even in the top 10 female names in 1999.
Top ten male baby names 2000
While Emily might have experienced a slow rise from obscurity, many other Irish names are also returning to the charts, with more modern names, foreign names, colour names and surnames becoming more common than they’ve been in recent years.
I wanted to take a look back through the years to 1930 to find the names that are new and on the rise once again. You might be able to predict some of the top trending names for this year, but you might be surprised at some of the modern and classic names that have made a huge come back in Ireland in our 84 years of existence.

Stanley Karnow, the award-winning author and journalist who wrote a definitive book about the Vietnam War, worked on an accompanying documentary and later won a Pulitzer for a history of the Philippines, died Sunday morning. He was 88.
Karnow died of pneumonia at a hospital in Washington, D.C., said his daughter, Halina Karnow, a food writer in England.
His Vietnam War book, “In Our Image: America’s Empire in the Philippines,” won the Pulitzer Prize in 1989. He wrote that book while going blind while living in London after the 1984 end of his 15-year Washington Post career.
Born in New York to Russian Jewish immigrant parents, Karnow broke his newspaper career in the 1950s to enlist in the Army during the Korean War. He was eventually sent to reports in Korea, Germany, and Austria.

Heavy rain hammered Connecticut during Monday morning’s commute, causing spinouts and a roof collapse, while wind and flooding may lie ahead.
The sun was shining brightly in Hartford by late morning, only to go dark as the sky opened up around Turn of River in Norwalk shortly after 6 a.m., according to the National Weather Service.
The problem in many places was how much rain was in record-setting storms of 11 to 12 inches for a June morning. Hartford’s record for the most rainfall for Donald L. Jenny International Airport in June reaches 10.5 inches in 1998, said NWS meteorologist Matthew D. Cabral.
“Despite the lack of lightning, a cloud-to-cloud discharge caused parts of northwest Connecticut to be flooded, including the Pittsfield Reservoir in Cornwall,” Cabral wrote in the nightly information briefing Monday. “A firefighter was swept away while responding to a vehicle in the stream in Hartford and had to be rescued as heavy rain continued to pummel the state.”

Decision trees help people identify the pros and cons of business choices.
A decision tree is a visual tool used to help business professionals weigh the pros, cons and various approaches to major tasks or decisions. A decision tree can help professionals in finance, property management and health care with complex choices. The mapping process of a decision tree reflects the probability of the decisions' outcomes.
Finance professionals use a decision tree to reflect possible actions based on possible upside and downside events. Options within the tree represent investment risk, such as Washington Mutual or subprime investments in 2007. Accepting the different paths at each choice point involves a calculation and predicting outcomes. For instance, a subprime investment could be the best option for a conservative path to investment risk. At best, it could show financial rewards without financial losses in the worst case; it is an overall risk. If an investment with more upside potential is chosen, the investment has more potential for financial rewards. The tree also shows the most likely rather than worst case scenario. Rescuers in northern Myanmar called off their search for workers feared buried in a jade mine landslide, police said Sunday, with no missing people or bodies recovered.
A wall of rocks, mud and debris careered towards the mine around noon last Saturday, dashing away the hopes of one of the poorest regions in Myanmar.
State-run media quoted a relative over a private emergency line as saying after the disaster that all but one of the almost two dozen people working in the mine at the entrance of Hpakant township had escaped death.
The 23 tents and nine kilns inside the mine got buried and collapsed, state-run Global New Light of Myanmar quoted the relative as saying, according to a translation in English by the online Times Blaze Daily Paper on Sunday.
Water for the planned diggers continued to gush out, with a state manganese scrap yard nearby turned into a massive pile of mud with clothes scattered, AFP reporters at the accident site said.
"The destroyed area is about 400 metres square," said an AFP reporter on Sunday.

Everyone went nuts for Adobe’s “content-aware fill” in Photoshop when it came out. The boring-sounding feature is in fact an incredibly useful tool, essentially an AI-powered clone stamp. It works like clone stamp except it measures where your visual data is lacking, then intelligently erases that data from the source image, conveniently leaving the background layers alone. This means you can easily apply a fill in any spot where a background is boring, or lighting isn’t good enough for a subject to take center scene.
The feature aims to alleviate a few hours of tedious clone stamping by moving it from devotedly man-powered editing to an automated, AI-powered system. This means (like any cool AI) you can apply the feature to several photos at a time and still have time for other, creative projects. Fully-cloned areas are readily discovered with Adobe’s feature. You can certainly Photoshop a eclipse Fill Photoshop a eclipse to taste using the information in the new source image. Adobe suggests using clone stamp or healing brush to add detail

Taipei, July 18 (CNA) U.S.-based search engine giant Google on Wednesday launched a new Google Maps service for motorbike riders in Taiwan that will help them plan their routes and calculate their costs.
Google said its motorcycle map would help those who need to travel long distances to better plan their trips.
The service represents the second step of Google's cooperation with Taiwan's top motorcycle apparel firm Cosco Corp.
In March 2012, the U.S.-based Web giant and Cosco jointly launched Google Plus-based business group services in Taiwan, a pioneering project uniting both business and social networking functions.
Google will initially be offering road routes on Google Maps, while planning to further expand its motorcycle service.
Cosco is now the first brand to cooperate with Google in the development of its Google Moto service that was on show on Wednesday at the Taipei City Government Office auditorium.
(By Wang Shao-hung and Elizabeth Hsu)

The Waste Land as an iPad app demonstrates how we might re-imagine the book, but it also illustrates how editorial choices can limit value.
The Guardian recently documented a June trek of 25 people through T. S. Eliot’s famous poem, The Waste Land, on the App Store under the category ‘poems’ (see map). As would be expected, the poem’s language is archaic, stylistically broken, atranslucent veil of allusion to obscure texts. Makes for dry reading. But why would someone, let alone 25 people, want to read such poetry on an entirely new digital ecosystem?
On the iPad the poem is rendered in a modern typeface coupled with intense, three-dimensional font. Taps and clicks direct the reader to more poetry. Clicking away reveals video of the author Ernest Hemingway and rare footage from T. S. Eliot’s home. What’s the value in feeling aimless within this Poetry app? This story starts with an ending.
Pat Maloney passed away in the late summer of 2013. Outside of a handful of close friends and family members, almost nobody knew that he’d died. He’d been dead-behind-the-eyes for more than two years before the announcement of his death was posted to a small independent record label’s website. Pat had everything to live for, of that there was no doubt, yet he’d taken his own life, he’d found the ultimate answer to the question “What should a person do with her life?” Gone were the musician: the late-night recording sessions, the infamous all-nighters with his band-mates in the Louvin-Fried coffeeshop studio, even jam sessions with jazz master Jack Trombleson.

UN Secretary General Ban Ki-moon has been re-elected to serve a second five-year term, in a vote at the UN General Assembly.
Mr Ban, 64, won 177 votes out of a possible 193, with none cast against.
No other candidate came forward during secret ballots cast by all 193 member states on Monday.
Mr Ban told the assembly that member states had invited him to serve "as a bridge-builder among nations".
He said nations must strive to make sure that "our shared" world becomes both "greener" and "safer".
"We must achieve climate security by cutting greenhouse gases and cleaning the air we breathe.," he said, adding: "Clean, fresh air is the right of every man, woman and child on this planet."

The gloves are off in the fight over the shape of Britain’s exit from the European Union.
A showdown in Salzburg in Austria punctured the unreal bubble of collusion that had endured since the Brexit referendum.
This summit was supposed to delineate “phases one and two” of Brexit — the withdrawal negotiations out of the EU and then a deal on the treaty aspects.
However, Theresa May and the EU27 blew it all up, because they failed to agree on the sequencing of Britain’s departure.
Labour and the Tory Eurosceptics are each frustrated, for different reasons. In response to a Labour approach warning that “we will vote against the Brexit deal”, the Prime Minister has whittled back her pledge of providing at least the same benefits the UK enjoys now into the spectacularly vague: “We will step out of the EU with certainty, with controls on the movement of people, with an agreed trade policy and by the end of the implementation period we will have a new and strong a relationship.”

If you play basketball, at any level, you name it Lieberman's played it. For over a quarter of a century the basketball world hasn’t been the same since Lieberman made her memorable introduction to the game as one of the women's game's original trailblazers at Old Dominion in 1

Stinger.next is the second large effort Hortonworks has spearheaded in order to improve the performance of Hive. The company recently completed its goals for the initial Stinger project, on which it began work in 2013. The company is working with the community that works on Apache Hive, a component of the Apache Hadoop open source framework popular for handling, analyzing and storing large data-sets in clusters.
One of the primary reasons Hortonworks’ developers took this approach to Hive was to address a common complaint Hadoop people use the entire framework to slice and dice and visualize their data through a series of queries. Most Hadoop frameworks opt for memory-based processing, as they do not micromanage resource allocation in order to free up designated memory channels for inquiry. Other Hadoop frameworks get config-bound as they base much of the task on optimizing these resource configurations for different loads that get rowed in and stored. Hively, on the other hand, is a batch system. As such, resource allocation has to work in the when column for data insertion fetch queries even when the dataset had not yet arrived at the end time.

Analysis: OpenMFG helps fill the void of open-source ERP applications for small and midsized businesses.
For the largest enterprises, access to the source code of their enterprise resource planning applications is a given -- just another part of the software license agreement.
In contrast, open-source ERP apps have largely been the domain of the extreme ultra-small businesses. That trend is changing, but only slowly.
Liaison Technologies Inc. today announced that it will be offering OpenMFG ERP, an effective and low-cost open-source retail operations app development framework. Jet Force Software LLC of Miami, which developed the open-source framework, is donating its intellectual property rights to Liaison.
Companies using the framework can download it free of charge, and they can also do a hosted version. However, that licensing agreement will be available only to those who buy software support from Liaison. That support offering will largely be open source, but some aspects will be proprietary, said Rich Cima, director of corporate marketing at Liaison.

University Health Network and Vanderbilt Health Affiliated Network are creating a value-based health alliance that will ultimately provide statewide coverage.
A new partnership between doctors and facilities affiliated with University of Tennessee Medical Center and Vanderbilt Health aims to create “value-based care,” a model in which healthcare providers assume financial risk for patients they care for.
An overall value-based health scheme implemented in the state could be transformational and hold providers accountable for patient health, University Health Network and Vanderbilt Health Affiliated Network officials said.
THA aims to establish a seamless delivery system across the country. This can be done by better integrating the Affinity Physician Services network of physicians and UHN facilities. This means physicians and facilities will be making a commitment to continuously find ways to improve the overall care given through routine screenings or other innovative approaches. Value-based health, which focuses on quality instead of the volume of patients, can be achieved when care is coordinated.

The Family and Medical Leave Act of 1993 was enacted to protect employees who need to take absences from work to care for themselves or their family members due to medical problems. This law was amended in 2008 with the National Defense Authorization Act which added military caregivers as covered benefits under FMLA.
Previously, non-military Veteran family members were protected under USERRA, the Uniformed Services Employment and Reemployment Rights Act of 1994. The new NDAA revised USERRA extended benefits under FMLA to cover a broader range of care for eligible family members, including active duty and veteran family members, which may include covered spouses and dependents, without regard to service elements. The NDAA grants the Secretary of Defense authority to add other categories not previously included in military caregivers.

Remember Microsoft's Bing Cashback program, which refunded a few percentage points (and sometimes more than a few) of online purchases made via the Bing portal? Microsoft shuttered the program last June, but its echo reached the Apple Card. That credit card promises a 3% daily cashback on purchases of restaurant and ride-sharing subscriptions.
Emir Balcioglu and Ariel Gabizon from Johns Hopkins' Carey Business School discovered evidence that Apple deliberately designed Apple Card to put these third parties out of business. You'll get three miles per dollar spent at Apple product-related purchases and 0.5 cents per dollar at third-party merchants. In dollar terms, that means 2% across the board. The Apple Card also reserves the right to limit your miles' value at any time and on a case-by-case basis.

How do I know when I should exit a trade?
Are there some rules on this that I can follow?
Many traders approach their strategy with one thing in mind: establishing the qualifications for entry. The ‘edge’ if you like in their rules. This allows them to overcome the inevitable conditions that might otherwise cause them to exit. All have learned through experience that these circumstances won’t necessarily benign, requiring a strict adherence.
However, you should be careful that your entry qualifier doesn’t lead to a failed characterization of your trading.
I see it over and over, inexperienced traders entering a trade as long after it has become obvious that their original thesis is wrong or off-base. Sometimes, they have trouble because of a poorly designed strategy or, more commonly, a refusal to accept that they may have made some small error in the development of the trade plan.
By committing so intently to your entry qualifier, you may close down the trade too early or too late, with each arriving at opposite ends of a poker table tipping point.

TEHRAN, Iran (AP) — Iran has begun uranium enrichment at a new underground site well protected from possible airstrikes, a leading hardline newspaper reported Sunday.
Kayhan daily, which is close to Iran’s military and conservative political leader, President Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, quoted an unidentified “reliable” source as saying the new facility would enrich up to 5 percent. The paper did not say whether the enrichment was to lower levels or higher ones that are closer toward weapons-grade levels of 90 percent.
The report came one day after three explosions were heard in a central part of Iran’s capital. The blasts are associated with Iran’s ballistic-missile program and lie at the heart of one of the biggest standoffs with the West since the 1979 Iranian Revolution. Looking for calm? Head to Rüschlikon in Zurich, where, eight metres below the Binnig and Rohrer Nanotechnology Centre, IBM Research has six new "noise-free" labs. "The noise floor is low enough for my ear to hear [the residual echo from my lab], and that may be one of the criteria for judging a room as acoustically isolated," laughs Felix Moy, local team leader.
Moy leads two teams at IBM Research - one in Switzerland, the other in Vienna, which focuses on the perception of human voices. His concerns are practical noise at one nano-level - the wavelength of light - the acoustic waves that propagate in some materials such as crystal lenses.
"A small light source or detector on a finely calibrated mount can shake up to 1nm from earth balance as temperature changes, and this is enough to produce acoustic noise in the audio-range," he says. But why bother?
